cars.name: McLaren MP4/4 '88
description: This McLaren race car competed in the 1988 F1 World Championship. The chassis was designed by Gordon Murray and Steve Nichols and is powered by a Honda RA168E engine. It would win 15 of the 16 races that season. The No. 12 MP4/4 was driven by Ayrton Senna. Senna performed extremely well, scoring 13 pole positions and 8 race victories to claim the drivers title.
cars.descriptionText: This McLaren race car competed in the 1988 F1 World Championship. The chassis was designed by Gordon Murray and Steve Nichols and is powered by a Honda RA168E engine. It would win 15 of the 16 races that season. The No. 12 MP4/4 was driven by Ayrton Senna. Senna performed extremely well, scoring 13 pole positions and 8 race victories to claim the drivers title.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz 190 E 2.5-16 Evolution II '91
description: Mercedes-Benz had been competing in the Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters (DTM) with the 190 E 2.3-16 since 1986. In 1990 they would introduce the ultimate form of the 2.5-16 as the 190 E 2.5-16 Evolution II. The stretched out fenders give the car a striking appearance that is matched by the newly tuned engine now producing 231.8 BHP. Produced in a limited run of just 500 units, the car would see some fantastic results in the 1992 DTM.

In 1990 they would introduce the ultimate form of the 2.5-16 as the 190 E 2.5-16 Evolution II. The stretched out fenders give the car a striking appearance that is matched by the newly tuned engine now producing 231.8 BHP. Produced in a limited run of just 500 units, the car would see some fantastic results in the 1992 DTM.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz 300 SL (W194) '52
description: The 300 SL race car, codename W194, uses a tubular frame chassis with aluminium panels, and features tuned versions of the engine and running gear from the type W186 300. This car would claim victory for Mercedes-Benz in its debut race at the 1952 24 Hours of Le Mans. Its racing performance prompted calls for a production model, leading to the development of the road car.

This car would claim victory for Mercedes-Benz in its debut race at the 1952 24 Hours of Le Mans. cars.name: Mercedes-Benz 300 SL Coupé '54
description: At the 1955 New York Auto Show, Daimler-Benz unveiled the Mercedes-Benz 300 SL. Though it was capable of an incredible top speed of 161.6 mph, the real attraction was its upward opening 'gullwing' doors that were hinged on the centre of the roof. 1,400 of these 300 SL 'gullwing' Coupés were produced between 1955 and 1957 before it passed the baton to the 300 SL Roadster.

Though it was capable of an incredible top speed of 161.6 mph, the real attraction was its upward opening 'gullwing' doors that were hinged on the centre of the roof. 1,400 of these 300 SL 'gullwing' Coupés were produced between 1955 and 1957 before it passed the baton to the 300 SL Roadster.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM '98
description: In order to compete in the FIA GT Championship which had begun in 1997, Mercedes-Benz and AMG developed the CLK-GTR in just 128 days. It featured V12 engine and claimed a double victory winning both the team and driver titles. The CLK-LM was introduced the next year as an evolution model. It would debut at the 24 Hours of Le Mans and went on to win all 10 rounds of the FIA GT Championship, claiming the season title.

It featured V12 engine and claimed a double victory winning both the team and driver titles. The CLK-LM was introduced the next year as an evolution model. It would debut at the 24 Hours of Le Mans and went on to win all 10 rounds of the FIA GT Championship, claiming the season title.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz S Barker Tourer '29
description: Double award winner at the 2017 Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance, taking both 'Best of Show' and the 'Gran Turismo Trophy'. Produced from 1926 to '33, what could be considered Mercedes-Benz's first sports car was designed by Ferdinand Porsche. It features a 7L supercharged straight six engine enveloped in beautiful 'boat tail' style bodywork by coachbuilder Barker.

Produced from 1926 to '33, what could be considered Mercedes-Benz's first sports car was designed by Ferdinand Porsche. It features a 7L supercharged straight six engine enveloped in beautiful 'boat tail' style bodywork by coachbuilder Barker.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz Sauber Mercedes C9 '89
description: The C9 is a Group C race car developed by Sauber of Switzerland. After previously providing engines for them, Mercedes took Sauber on as the factory team in 1988. In '89, the car appeared with an all silver body, inciting flashbacks of the Silver Arrows. In an astonishing result at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, car 63 took first place with 61 in second and 62 in fifth.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz SLR McLaren '09
description: The SLR McLaren is a production model of the 1999 Mercedes-Benz Vision SLR concept car. The most notable feature is its carbon fibre monocoque body which has greatly reduced weight. The power unit is a 5.5L V8 SOHC engine with a twin-screw supercharger, connected to a 5-speed automatic transmission which offers sport, comfort and manual modes.

The power unit is a 5.5L V8 SOHC engine with a twin-screw supercharger, connected to a 5-speed automatic transmission which offers sport, comfort and manual modes.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz Unimog Type 411 '62
description: The Unimog is a commercial vehicle constructed and sold by Daimler Truck. First produced in 1948, it would prove to be a long-seller as a multi-purpose vehicle. The 411 series is a successor model introduced in 1956, featuring a more powerful engine and stronger body. Between the 3 wheelbase options and multiple body types, there are 12 different models in the lineup, which can be further modified with a variety of attachments.

cars.name: Mercedes-Benz W 196 R '55
description: The W 196 was developed by Mercedes-Benz looking towards F1 regulations which were moving to 2.5L from 1954. The W 196 R was constructed for use in F1. The 2,496 cc inline-8 engine produces 285 BHP and is able to reach a top speed of 180.2 mph. It would achieve incredible results in the 1954 and 1955 F1 World Championship, with driver Juan Manuel Fangio taking the drivers' title 2 years running.

cars.name: Mine's BNR34 GT-R N1 base
description: Created by Mine's, the 'BNR34 GT-R N1 base' is a complete tuned model that explores the beauty of the R34 model GT-R, while keeping to the tenets of street car style. From the tuning of the RB26DETT, to the low-slung suspension, to the understated exterior, everything has been crafted under the philosophy of Mine's CEO Michizo Niikura, to create 'a first-class street car'. This car was fully restored in 2021 by Garage Yoshida.

cars.name: MINI MINI Clubman VGT
description: This Vision Gran Turismo brings us the visage of a MINI built to race. With a 1,050 kg lightweight body and 389.5 BHP of power, the car is able to achieve a 0-62.1 mph time of just 3.5 seconds. The drive system powers all four wheels. With its low silhouette lying almost flat on the ground and wheels edged out to their very limit, the car is able to achieve the excellent go-kart like handling that MINIs are famed for, making for an incredible driving experience.

cars.name: MINI MINI Cooper S '05
description: This is a hot hatch model of the new MINI after their takeover by BMW. The 1.6L inline-4 engine has been supercharged to produce 167.7 BHP/22 kgfm, an increase of 53.3 BHP/7 kgfm over the Cooper. Also featuring an exclusive 6-speed manual transmission, this car concentrates all the joy of driving into a compact package.

cars.name: MINI Mini-Cooper 'S' '65
description: In order to fully utilize the MINI's exceptional handling, the BMC (British Motor Corporation) came together with F1 constructor John Cooper to create this sports model. The 970 'S' was a version of the car with the engine displacement adjusted to 970 cc to fit racing class requirements. While the standard 848 cc engine produced 33.5 BHP, this version produces 65.1 BHP. Though only 963 such cars were produced, it was very successful in touring car races.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Concept XR-PHEV EVOLUTION VGT
description: This Vision Gran Turismo was created by Mitsubishi Motors who have an exceptional track record in races like the Dakar Rally and the World Rally Championship (WRC.) While taking cues from the 'Mitsubishi Concept XR-PHEV' displayed at the 2013 Tokyo Motor Show, the idea has been developed into a spirited racing machine. A plug-in hybrid EV, combining electric motors with a conventional engine, it directs its immense power to all 4 wheels through the S-AWC vehicle dynamics control system.

cars.name: Mitsubishi FTO GP Version R '97
description: The FTO was released in 1994, making a comeback 23 years after the release of the original model. The body uses Japanese market mid-size proportions, which was quite rare for its time, and is notable for its relatively large body width. There were 3 engine options available, the '4G93' model 1.8L I4 SOHC, the '6A12' model 2L V6 DOHC, and a high-tuned version of the 6A12, boasting 197.2 BHP. This GP Version R was a high-performance model equipped with sports suspension, a limited-slip differential, and front and rear strut tower bars as standard.

cars.name: Mitsubishi GTO Twin Turbo '91
description: Debuting in 1990, the GTO was Mitsubishi's first true sports car in many years. The large, glamorous body styling was aimed at the American market. It also featured a number of advanced technologies such as the all-wheel control and 4-wheel steering, electronically controlled suspension and active aero parts. The engine was a 3L V6 unit available either twin turbocharged or naturally aspirated. It was sold overseas as the 3000GT where it found popularity for its aggressive performance.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution Final '15
description: Limited to 1000 cars, this is the final model of the Lancer Evolution X. The 'X' does not appear anywhere on the body however, discreetly indicating that this in fact may be the final Lancer Evolution. Based on the 5-speed manual GSR model, the engine produces 308.7 BHP/43 kgfm now equipped with sodium filled exhaust valve stems. This version also includes the 'high-performance package' with Bilstein dampers and Eibach springs.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution Final Gr.3
description: This Gran Turismo Original is a version of Mitsubishi's high performance sedan, the Lancer Evolution Final Edition, modified for Gr.3 regulations. This function-first design has removed all unnecessary embellishments. Slits on the front fenders push turbulent air out from the wheel well and numerous winglets inside the fender reshape the air moving across the whole body.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution Final Gr.4
description: This Gran Turismo Original is a version of Mitsubishi's high performance sedan, the Lancer Evolution Final Edition, modified for Gr.4 regulations. The Lancer had seen great success in real world touring car races, and this version should be no less successful as it uses the Lancer's proprietary electronically controlled four-wheel drive system to achieve impressive turning power.

cars.model: Lancer Evolution Final Gr.B Rally Car
cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution Final Gr.B Rally Car
description: This Gran Turismo Original is a version of Mitsubishi's high performance sedan, the Lancer Evolution Final Edition, modified for Gr.B regulations. The white, silver and red design of this rally car is an homage to World Rally cars of the past. The Gr.3 style aero parts provide strong downforce giving this car potential to go up against even modern WRC cars.

cars.model: Lancer Evolution Final Gr.B Road Car
cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution Final Gr.B Road Car
description: A homologation model of the Gran Turismo Original Lancer Evolution Final Edition Gr.B, itself based on Mitsubishi's high performance sedan. While created as a rally base car, the almost perfect 50:50 weight distribution, and extended rear wing means that even on-road this car is capable of turning corners in a way unlike any other four-wheel drive car.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution III GSR '95
description: The 3rd Lancer Evolution model was released in January 1995. In order to improve racing performance, much attention has been paid to the aerodynamics and cooling, as seen in the now-larger open mouth of the front bumper and the large boot-mounted spoiler. The classic 4G63 engine has been further tuned to produce 266.3 BHP. In the 1996 World Rally Championship, Tommi Mäkinen won the drivers' title in this car.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution IV GSR '96
description: In August 1996, the 2nd generation Lancer was released and with it came the Lancer Evolution IV. The 4G63, flipped 180 degrees in respect to previous models, now produced 276.1 BHP with a maximum torque of 36 kgfm. For the rear differential, the previous mechanical LSD was replaced with an electronically controlled AYC (Active Yaw Control) system, allowing for much more controllable handling.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution IX MR GSR '06
description: The Lancer Evolution IX GSR features the initials of Mitsubishi Racing (MR). Performance has been enhanced across the board, with the engine's MIVEC settings tuned to improve turbo response, while the suspension has been improved through the use of Eibach springs and a new AYC tune. This would be the last Lancer Evolution to feature the classic 4G63 engine and is the pinnacle of the 3rd wave Lancer Evolution cars.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution V GSR '98
description: The 5th model of the Lancer Evolution was introduced in January 1998. Looking towards competition in the World Rally Championship, the body was widened and the 4G63 was tuned for extra torque. The electronically controlled AYC (Active Yaw Control) introduced on the previous model was carried over, and new inverted dampers and a front helical LSD were added for extra performance.

cars.model: Lancer Evolution VI GSR T.M. SCP '99
cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VI GSR T.M. SCP '99
description: This special edition of the Lancer Evolution VI was introduced to commemorate Tommi Mäkinen's achievement of 4 consecutive WRC drivers' champion titles. Set up for tarmac rallies, the ride height has been lowered by 10 mm and low-end torque has been increased for practicality. It was sold in a limited run of 2500 cars, featuring an exclusive red body colour and seats, along with special alloy wheels and a large-diameter silencer.

cars.name: Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VIII MR GSR '04
description: The 8th model of the Lancer Evolution was released in January 2003. Refinements were made to the ACD (Active Centre Differential) and AYC control systems from the previous model enhancing ride quality. The 4G63 engine's maximum torque now reached 40 kgfm and with the new 6-speed manual transmission, the car can perform its best in all conditions.

cars.name: Nismo 400R '95
description: In an era where Japanese passenger cars were typically limited to 276.1 BHP, NISMO introduced this complete tuned car which produced a maximum 394.5 BHP. It uses an enlarged 2.8L version of the classic RB26 engine known as the RB-X GT2 fitted with an N1 spec turbine. The suspension features Bilstein dampers along with upgraded stabilizers and bushings. The fenders have been stretched out to house the wider tyres, giving a hint at this car's incredible performance.
cars.descriptionText: In an era where Japanese passenger cars were typically limited to 276.1 BHP, NISMO introduced this complete tuned car which produced a maximum 394.5 BHP. It uses an enlarged 2.8L version of the classic RB26 engine known as the RB-X GT2 fitted with an N1 spec turbine. The suspension features Bilstein dampers along with upgraded stabilizers and bushings. The fenders have been stretched out to house the wider tyres, giving a hint at this car's incredible performance.

cars.name: Nismo R34 GT-R Z-tune '05
description: The NISMO R34 GT-R Z-tune is a comprehensively tuned complete custom package. Based on the R34 model Skyline GT-R, the engine has swapped for a 2.8L version of the RB26DETT Kai-Z2 used in GT500 class racing. Body rigidity has been improved through extra spot welds and additional carbon fibre parts, alongside fine adjustments to suspension and brakes, which all speaks to NISMO’s commitment to tuning. Including the original prototype, only 19 of these cars were ever produced.

cars.name: Nissan 180SX Type X '96
description: The 180SX was introduced in March 1989 as a liftback model of the S13 model Silvia. Production was originally scheduled to end along with the S13 when the Silvia received a full model change. However, the US-spec 240SX with its 2.4L engine showed no signs of slowing down in sales, leading Nissan to break the model away from the Silvia line and continue production. The 180SX was particularly popular with custom car fans who created their own unique cars.

The 180SX was particularly popular with custom car fans who created their own unique cars.

cars.name: Nissan Fairlady 240ZG (HS30) '71
description: Introduced in 1969, the Fairlady Z was one of the first Japanese cars to compete on the international stage. The symbolic model is the Z 432 which uses an S20 inline-6 DOHC engine derived from the Prince R380 instead of the standard L-type engine. With a maximum power output of 157.8 BHP it also saw use in motorsports. The 240Z is a US spec model with a 2.4L engine, and made 'Z' the byword for sports cars after its success in the Safari and Monte Carlo rallies.

cars.name: Nissan Fairlady Z (Z34) '08
description: Introduced in 2008, the 6th generation Fairlady Z (Z34) was a full model change with a strong resemblance to the previous Z33 model. It shared the same platform as the V36 model Skyline Coupé and features a lighter body with performance improvements. The VQ37VHR produces 331.4 BHP. This performance oriented model also features optimizations in the suspension and brakes.

This performance oriented model also features optimizations in the suspension and brakes.

cars.name: Nissan Fairlady Z 300ZX TT 2seater '89
description: The 4th generation Fairlady Z was designed for the global market, largely ignoring Japanese domestic size restrictions. The wider body allowed for an increased track width, giving it new found abilities for cornering. The engine was a 3L V6 in the front-midship position, with the naturally aspirated model producing 226.8 BHP and 276.1 BHP for the twin-turbo model.

cars.name: Nissan Fairlady Z 432 '69
description: Introduced in 1969 as the top grade model of the Fairlady Z, the Z 432 features an inline-6 DOHC 'S20' engine producing 157.8 BHP. This engine is based on that of Nissan's R380 race car and is capable of a 0-400 m time of 15.8s and a top speed of 130.5 mph. It also saw use in racing. Additionally, a Z 432 R model was sold in very small numbers and used fibreglass and acrylic parts to reduce weight.

cars.name: Nissan Fairlady Z Version S (Z33) '07
description: An improved version of the Z33 Fairlady Z released in 2007. The new VQ35HR engine has increased the power to 308.7 BHP and the intake manifold and reduced friction have improved engine feeling at high revolutions. Suspension settings have also been changed to create a more flat and flexible profile.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R '17
description: In 2016, the Nissan GT-R received its most drastic facelift upgrade since its original release in 2007. The exterior balances air resistance, downforce and cooling performance. Meanwhile, the 565.1 BHP producing 3.8L V6 twin-turbo engine and improved 6-speed dual clutch transmission provide smoother acceleration and better cornering performance. These 'deeper' evolutions make this a prime example of the character of Japanese sports cars.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R Gr.4
description: Nissan's 'multi-performance' R35 GT-R has been modified for Gr.4 competition in this Gran Turismo Original. The four-wheel drive system provides handling stability, and other endurance racing items like the fog lamps make it a perfect machine for the long run.
cars.descriptionText: Nissan's 'multi-performance' R35 GT-R has been modified for Gr.4 competition in this Gran Turismo Original. The four-wheel drive system provides handling stability, and other endurance racing items like the fog lamps make it a perfect machine for the long run.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R Gr.B Rally Car
description: Nissan's 'multi-performance' R35 GT-R has been modified for Gr.B competition in this Gran Turismo Original. The most obvious exterior changes are the quad fog lamps on the bonnet and the large fog lamps on each side of the bumper for lighting up the track on night stages. The already superb four-wheel drive system gives the GT-R an edge in rallying as well.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R GT500 '08
description: After a surprise comeback, the Nissan GT-R began competition in the 2008 Super GT championship. Looking towards regulations from the next year, this car uses a pipe frame body and uses the same 4.5L V8 engine carried over from the Z. The XANAVI NISMO car showed incredible speed from the very first round and went on to win the drivers title.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R GT500 '99
description: This R34 model GT-R competed in the 1999 All Japan GT Championship. The wheelbase has been shortened 55 mm over the previous R33 model, and the engine position has been adjusted using a shallow oil pan, greatly increasing overall performance. At round 4's Mine Circuit, Erik Comas and Satoshi Motoyama drove to victory in the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R, winning Comas his second consecutive drivers title.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R LM NISMO '15
description: In spring 2014, Nissan announced that they would be entering a car bearing the GT-R badge in the 24 Hours of Le Mans. This GT-R LM NISMO featured a revolutionary front-engine front-wheel drive construction. The carbon fibre body was designed by Ben Bowlby, the man behind the DeltaWing and ZEOD RC, and is equipped with a 3L V6 twin-turbo engine and energy recovery system. Weighing the minimum 880 kg, it competed for overall victory.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R NISMO '17
description: The 2017 model of the GT-R NISMO features various improvements throughout the car. While retaining its bonded body construction and the engine specs, the front window frame has been strengthened to increase rigidity, and comfort levels have been increased for both urban and circuit driving. Aerodynamics have also been improved and thanks to a full redesign by the engineers, the body also generates more downforce at high speeds.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R NISMO GT3 '13
description: In 2013, Gran Turismo series producer Kazunori Yamauchi collaborated with Schulze Motorsport. The GT-R GT3 was created especially to participate in the Nürburgring 24 Hours thanks to the technical skills of Polyphony Digital. The data collected from this car was used to improve Gran Turismo's simulation engine.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R NISMO GT3 '18
description: The Nissan GT-R NISMO GT3 is an FIA GT3 regulation production racing car based on the R35 model GT-R. The base model was later changed to the GT-R NISMO which used a dry sump system to lower the centre of gravity and optimize weight distribution. Extra front rigidity and newly designed suspension helped improve handling response. The changes to the engine room layout also improved cooling efficiency, which also helped with stability at high speeds.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R NISMO GT500 '16
description: The new rules for 2014 meant that the car would use the same monocoque weight and other main parts as the DTM version. As such major changes were made to the GT500 spec GT-R, with further improvements made up to the 2016 model. In the 2014 and '15 seasons, the MOTUL AUTECH GT-R was crowned series champion. The team had hoped for a third consecutive win in 2016, but finished 3rd overall.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R Premium edition T-spec '24
description: The introduction of the 2024 model GT-R quashed rumours that production had ended with the 2022 model. A new exhaust silencer setup allowed the car to preserve its performance while clearing noise regulations. The exterior was also improved, increasing downforce. Additionally, the introduction of high sensitivity G-sensors in the electronically controlled suspension not only improved traction, but ride comfort as well.

cars.name: Nissan GT-R Safety Car
description: This Gran Turismo Original turns Nissan's R35 GT-R supercar into a safety car. The roof-mounted LED patrol lights and light arrays on the front and rear bumper have greatly increased its visibility. The centre console also features extra switches exclusive to this model.
cars.descriptionText: This Gran Turismo Original turns Nissan's R35 GT-R supercar into a safety car. The roof-mounted LED patrol lights and light arrays on the front and rear bumper have greatly increased its visibility. The centre console also features extra switches exclusive to this model.

cars.name: Nissan NISSAN CONCEPT 2020 VGT
description: This Vision Gran Turismo portrays a not too distant vision of the future for Nissan, realized through the collaboration of young group of British designers and Japanese engineers. The powertrain combines a V6 twin-turbo with 3 electric motors to create the performance hybrid FR-4WD system. Using active suspension to take full advantage of its aerodynamic prowess, the car is always ready to unleash its full performance unto the driver at any moment.
cars.descriptionText: This Vision Gran Turismo portrays a not too distant vision of the future for Nissan, realized through the collaboration of young group of British designers and Japanese engineers. The powertrain combines a V6 twin-turbo with 3 electric motors to create the performance hybrid FR-4WD system. Using active suspension to take full advantage of its aerodynamic prowess, the car is always ready to unleash its full performance unto the driver at any moment.

cars.name: Nissan Qashqai Tekna e-Power '22
description: The Qashqai is a compact SUV which debuted in 2006 and occupies the C-segment of Nissan’s lineup. The third generation model featured a larger body with an overhauled exterior design. This car is available with Nissan’s proprietary ‘e-Power’ series hybrid drivetrain, which uses a conventional engine to turn an electric generator which provides power to the electric motors which drive the wheels. The ‘Tekna’ grade model includes a wealth of equipment as standard, including larger wheel rims, ambient lights and a head-up display.

cars.name: Nissan R32 GT-R NISMO '90
description: This homologation model of the R32 model Skyline GT-R was sold in a limited run of 500 units. Looking to claim victory in Group A, cooling improvements were implemented across the board, the turbocharger turbine was switched for a metal part, and the body was modified to improve aerodynamics and reduce weight. The performance increase was significant, and the car would win numerous touring car races, not only in Japan, but across Europe and Australia as well.

cars.name: Nissan R32 GT-R V･spec II '94
description: The R32 Skyline GT-R would be the first car in 16 years to carry the GT-R name since the discontinuation of the 'Kenmeri.' The newly developed RB26DETT engine was equipped with ceramic twin turbos to produce 276.1 BHP/36 kgfm. The drive system used the revolutionary ATTESA E-TS four-wheel drive system which was developed with a focus on making the car turn. The V-Spec II was a high performance grade introduced in 1994, and was equipped with wider 245/45R17 tyres.

cars.name: Nissan R33 GT-R V･spec '97
description: The R33 GT-R was released in January 1995. In response to the question of how they improved on the previous generation which may well be remembered as one of history's greatest cars, Nissan advertised the new car under the catchphrase the 'Minus 21 second Dream', referring to the R33's lap time on the Nürburgring, where it had beaten the R32 by 21 seconds. The RB26DETT engine was carried over to the new model with improved engine response and torque. The V-Spec model was also equipped with ATTESA E-TS Pro four-wheel drive system as standard, which gave combined control over the active LSD and ABS braking systems.

cars.name: Nissan R34 GT-R V･spec II Nür '02
description: The R34 GT-R debuted in January 1999. In contrast to the larger R33, the new car featured a more toned muscular body, being 75 mm shorter with a 55 mm shorter wheelbase. The thoroughly matured RB26DETT was given a further increase in torque to 40 kgfm, and along with chassis improvements the car gained a new level of controllability with more predictable handling. The 'Nür' was the final limited edition model released and was equipped with an N1 spec RB26DETT engine.

cars.name: Nissan R92CP '92
description: After it was decided that the All Japan GT Championship would continue with the old turbocharger rules until 1992, Nissan continued development of their cars culminating in the R92CP. With a top speed recorded on the main straight of Fuji Speedway at over 248.5 mph and producing up to 3.5 tons of downforce, the R92CP was unstoppable, winning every race of the season, and closing out the turbo era.

cars.name: Nissan Sileighty '98
description: The 180SX was introduced as a liftback model of the S13 model Silvia. On performance, it was heavier than the Silvia, and lacked rigidity in the rear, but a number of tuning parts were soon released and fans began to create their own original setups. One of the most famous modifications was to outfit the 180SX with the front fascia of the S13, creating what was called the 'Sileighty.'

cars.name: Nissan Silvia K's Aero (S14) '96
description: The S14 model Silvia features a larger body than the S13. In 1996, a major facelift was carried out, adding the scowling headlights and a large rear spoiler. The 'Aero' is a higher grade model available for both the K's and Q's which includes special bumpers, front and rear spoilers, a leather wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, along with white meter faces as standard.
cars.descriptionText: The S14 model Silvia features a larger body than the S13. In 1996, a major facelift was carried out, adding the scowling headlights and a large rear spoiler. cars.name: Nissan Silvia K's Dia Selection (S13) '90
description: Produced from 1988 to 1993, the S13 model Silvia garnered countless fans for the enjoyable handling of its compact, rear-wheel drive setup. Of these models, the high performance K's with its turbocharged inline-4 DOHC 'CA18ET' engine was particularly well regarded for its great potential on any given stage. The 'Dia Selection' was later introduced as a low cost model.

cars.name: Nissan Silvia K's Type S (S14) '94
description: The wider body of the S14 model Silvia provided an extra feeling of luxury. The engine is a returned version of the SR20 from the S13 and is further equipped with an intercooled turbocharger on the top grade K's model. The basic suspension setup has also been carried over from the S13 with struts on the front and a multilink setup on the rear. A model with electric Super HICAS was also available.

cars.name: Nissan Silvia Q's (S13) '88
description: Produced from 1988 to 1993, the S13 model Silvia garnered countless fans for the enjoyable handling of its compact, rear-wheel drive setup. While the top grade K's model featured a turbocharged engine, the Q's featured a 138.1 BHP naturally aspirated unit. The suspension uses struts on the front with a multilink system on the rear, and was also available with 'Super HICAS' four-wheel steering.

cars.name: Nissan Silvia spec-R Aero (S15) '02
description: The 7th generation S15 Silvia returned to a more compact model similar to the S13, transforming into an affordable rear-wheel drive sports car. It carried over the SR20 from the models before it, but the running gear and suspension received a major overhaul. Increased body rigidity, upgraded brakes, sportier suspension and a helical LSD all provided a much higher level of performance than its predecessors.

cars.name: Nissan Skyline 2000GT-R (KPGC110) '73
description: This is a high performance model of the 4th generation 'C110' Skyline. Larger than the previous model, this new body features the same S20 straight six engine as the 'Hakosuka' GT-R and is now fitted with 4-wheel disc brakes. This car was created to carry on the legacy of the GT-R, but new emissions standards meant that it would finish its career before ever participating in a single race. Only 197 were produced.

cars.name: Nissan Skyline GTS-R (R31) '87
description: This high performance model of the 7th gen Skyline was introduced to compete in Group A races. The RB20DET engine has been modified, fitting it with a stainless steel exhaust manifold and a T04E turbocharger, alongside other changes to the suspension and exterior. It would claim the season title at the 1989 All Japan Touring Car Championship, but it also left fans asking why it wasn't called a GT-R.
cars.descriptionText: This high performance model of the 7th gen Skyline was introduced to compete in Group A races. cars.name: Nissan Skyline Hard Top 2000GT-R (KPGC10) '70
description: This is a high performance model of the C10 model Skyline, nicknamed the 'Hakosuka,' introduced in February 1969. It features bolt-on overfenders and an S20 DOHC engine derived from the R380 racing car. It had an unprecedented racing record, winning 52 races, 49 consecutively before the factory racing team ceased operations. The legend of the Skyline originates with this car.

cars.name: Nissan Skyline Super Silhouette '84
description: The Skyline Super Silhouette is a silhouette formula car (a race car that only uses the basic shape of the production model) based on the 6th generation Skyline. Adorned with wide front and rear fenders and a large rear wing, the body houses 2.1L 4-cylinder turbo 'LZ20B' racing engine. This car would claim 8 wins between 1982 and 1984.

cars.name: Nissan Z Performance '23
description: This production model of the 7th generation Fairlady Z first appeared as a prototype in 2020. Nissan chose not to use an electric drivetrain, instead utilising a VR30DDTT 3L V6 twin-turbo engine connected to either a 6-speed manual transmission or 9-speed automatic with manual shift mode. While the automotive industry as a whole looks towards revolutions in self-driving and electrification, this car chases the romanticism of a front engine, rear-wheel drive sports car.
cars.descriptionText: This production model of the 7th generation Fairlady Z first appeared as a prototype in 2020. Nissan chose not to use an electric drivetrain, instead utilising a VR30DDTT 3L V6 twin-turbo engine connected to either a 6-speed manual transmission or 9-speed automatic with manual shift mode. While the automotive industry as a whole looks towards revolutions in self-driving and electrification, this car chases the romanticism of a front engine, rear-wheel drive sports car.

cars.name: Opel Opel Corsa GSE VGT
description: The Opel Corsa GSE Vision Gran Turismo is a fully electric high-performance concept car that combines Opel’s respect for tradition with its passion for futuristic technology. Two electric motors, one on each axle, provide a total system output of 588 kW (788 BHP). This allows the car to accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in just 2 seconds, and ultimately reach a top speed of 198.8 mph. It also features excellent aerodynamic performance, with features like an active aero diffusor and spoiler that ensure stability at high speeds.

cars.name: Pagani Huayra '13
description: Pagani introduced the Huayra in 2011 to replace the Zonda. The monocoque frame uses a combination of carbon and titanium, and features gullwing doors, merging exquisite design with high performance. The AMG 6L V12 twin-turbo engine is mated to a 7-speed sequential transmission and is capable of a 0-62.1 mph time of 3.2s and a top speed of 234.9 mph.

cars.name: Pagani Zonda R '09
description: A track-only development of the Zonda, released in 1999. The midship mounted AMG V12 produces 739.6 BHP/72 kgfm. Meanwhile the wheelbase and track width have been increased to improve stability. It has a top speed of 217.5 mph and can accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in just 2.7s.

cars.name: Peugeot 2008 Allure '21
description: The Peugeot 2008 was introduced in 2013. This featured 2008 SUV is a second generation model. It uses the same platform as Peugeot's '208' hatchback model. The lights feature motifs of a lion's claws and fangs. Another notable feature of this compact SUV is the '3D i-Cockpit' which consists of a small diameter steering wheel with a flattened top and bottom, and a head-up digital instrument panel centred above it.

cars.name: Peugeot 205 GTI '88
description: The 205 GTI was released as a sports model in the image of Peugeot's '205 Turbo 16' World Rally Championship car. The lightweight, compact body was equipped with a lively 1.6L SOHC engine, resulting in all-around excellent performance. This masterpiece of French automotive engineering would sell over 300,000 units in Europe alone, making it an absolutely essential part of 1980s-90s car history.

This masterpiece of French automotive engineering would sell over 300,000 units in Europe alone, making it an absolutely essential part of 1980s-90s car history.

cars.name: Peugeot 205 Turbo 16 Evolution 2 '86
description: The 205 Turbo 16 is a Group B machine produced by Peugeot for the World Rally Championship. This car won 3 rounds in its debut year of 1984, and another 3 in 1985. Peugeot developed the car further though improving weight, power and aerodynamics to create the Evolution 2 model. This new version would win 7 out of 12 rounds in 1985 and 6 out of 13 in 1986, claiming 2 consecutive titles in both the drivers and manufacturers championships.

This new version would win 7 out of 12 rounds in 1985 and 6 out of 13 in 1986, claiming 2 consecutive titles in both the drivers and manufacturers championships.

cars.name: Peugeot 208 GTi by Peugeot Sport '14
description: The 208 GTi is the sports model of Peugeot's 208, a mainstream compact car. The body is smaller than the previous 207 and, through an overhaul of construction and materials across the car, is over 100 kg lighter. With a top speed of 142.9 mph and a 0-62.1 mph time of 6.8 seconds, this car sits at the forefront of the hot hatches.

cars.name: Peugeot 908 HDi FAP '10
description: The 908 HDi FAP was developed by Peugeot to reach the pinnacle of prototype car racing. In 2007 and 2008, it would compete in the events like the LMS to further research and development. In 2009, it would finally beat its rival at Le Mans, Audi's diesel engine R10, in a glorious 1-2 finish. While it was unable to achieve a successive victory in 2010, it still performed admirably.

cars.name: Peugeot L500R HYbrid VGT 2017
description: This Vision Gran Turismo was born as an homage to Peugeot's victory at the 1916 Indy 500 Mile Race. At just 1 m tall the car has a stunningly low slung design and its gradually tapered tail is shared with the Indy winning L45 machine. The powertrain is a hybrid system combining a 1.6L 4-cylinder turbo engine with two electric motors for a total power output of 500BHP/730Nm (493.1 BHP/74 kgfm).

cars.name: Peugeot L750R HYbrid VGT 2017
description: This is a competition model of the L500R HYbrid Vision Gran Turismo. The rev limiter of the L500R's 1.6L 4-cylinder engine has been raised to 10,000rpm, pushing maximum power output up to 580 horsepower. Combined with the 170 produced by the electric motors, the total combined power output is 750 hp. On the exterior a large under spoiler has been added to the front of the car and paired with a large rear wing to increase downforce.

cars.name: Peugeot PEUGEOT VGT
description: The PEUGEOT Vision Gran Turismo was born from the minds of the design team of Peugeot and the engineers of Peugeot Sport. With a height of just 1 m, the body hugs the ground and together with its 3.2L V6 turbo engine producing an unrelenting 875ch (874.8 BHP) you can see that this car was developed with a singular focus on driving.

cars.name: Peugeot PEUGEOT VGT (Gr.3)
description: This Gran Turismo Original is a Gr.3 modified version of the PEUGEOT Vision Gran Turismo which was created in a collaboration between Peugeot and Gran Turismo. To produce extra downforce, the front splitter and rear diffuser have been enlarged, and a swan-neck wing has been added to the rear.
cars.descriptionText: This Gran Turismo Original is a Gr.3 modified version of the PEUGEOT Vision Gran Turismo which was created in a collaboration between Peugeot and Gran Turismo. To produce extra downforce, the front splitter and rear diffuser have been enlarged, and a swan-neck wing has been added to the rear.

cars.name: Peugeot RCZ Gr.3
description: A Gran Turismo Original, this is a version of the RCZ, Peugeot's elegant flowing specialty car, modified for Gr.3 rules. In order to improve weight distribution and overall performance, the car drivetrain has been converted from a front-engine front-wheel drive system to a midship rear-wheel drive layout. With its long 2,612 mm wheelbase the RCZ is the perfect candidate for race car conversion.

cars.name: Peugeot RCZ Gr.3 Road Car
description: This is a homologation model of the RCZ Gr.3, a version of the RCZ, Peugeot's elegant flowing specialty car, modified for Gr.3 rules. The car has been reborn as a midship supercar that takes cues from the 2002 'RC' concept, one of the earliest incarnations of what would become RCZ.

cars.name: Peugeot RCZ Gr.4
description: A Gran Turismo Original, this is a version of the RCZ, Peugeot's elegant flowing specialty car, modified for Gr.4 rules. Set up as an orthodox front-wheel drive touring car, the RCZ Gr.4 adds a front splitter and rear wing, as well as new, more aerodynamic front fenders.

cars.name: Peugeot RCZ Gr.B Rally Car
description: A Gran Turismo Original, this is a version of the RCZ, Peugeot's elegant flowing specialty car, modified for Gr.B rules. This model has been designed in the image of Pikes Peak cars, featuring an extra large front spoiler and rear wing. The engine has been moved to behind the cockpit and now uses a four-wheel drive powertrain.

cars.name: Peugeot RCZ GT Line '15
description: Gaining widespread attention after its unveiling as a concept car at the 2007 Frankfurt Motor Show, the Peugeot RCZ was released to the public in 2010 barely unchanged from its concept format. In 2015 the GT Line model was added, featuring a new front grille and dual exhaust pipes, as well as 19-inch wheels and a new red-stitched black leather interior for a much sportier look.

cars.name: Plymouth Superbird '70
description: A homologation model released by Plymouth under the Chrysler umbrella, aimed at competition in stock car racing. The base Road Runner has been fitted with a long nose extension and a massive rear wing to create a unique look. It came with the 369.8 BHP 440 Super Commando engine as standard, with a 426 Hemi producing over 419.1 BHP and a 384.6 BHP six barrel also available as options. It was produced for the homologation period of only one year.

cars.name: Plymouth XNR Ghia Roadster '60
description: A masterpiece roadster created by master designer Virgil Exner in 1960. The asymmetrical styling, bonnet bulge and aero fins all give the impression that this is Exner's take on the 1950s race car. It would win the Gran Turismo Trophy in 2011.
cars.descriptionText: A masterpiece roadster created by master designer Virgil Exner in 1960. The asymmetrical styling, bonnet bulge and aero fins all give the impression that this is Exner's take on the 1950s race car. It would win the Gran Turismo Trophy in 2011.

cars.name: Polestar Polestar 5 Performance '26
description: Created by the Scandinavian electric car brand Polestar, the Polestar 5 is an all-wheel drive electric saloon featuring a 5 m long streamlined body with a glass roof that stretches to the rear of the car. It is powered by a dual-motor setup featuring a motor on each of the front and rear axles. The Performance model is able to produce 650 kW/1,015 Nm. The 800V electrical architecture can use 350 kW fast-charging, allowing the battery to charge from 10 to 80% in just 22 min. The maximum range is 416.3 miles under WLTP mode testing (dual-motor version).

cars.name: Pontiac Firebird Trans Am '78
description: The representative muscle car of the 1970s. The large firebird decal on the bonnet was extremely popular with young enthusiasts at the time. It was the sister car to the Chevrolet Camaro, but the top grade Trans Am featured a special 6.6L engine that was unavailable on the Camaro, making it the pride of Pontiac.

cars.name: Pontiac GTO 'The Judge' '69
description: Introduced in 1968, the 2nd generation Pontiac GTO is said to be one of the originators of the muscle car, but it had many powerful rivals. 'The Judge' was a sports package designed to end the argument. The package, which included a 6.6L V8 'Ram Air III' engine, Hurst shifter, heavy duty suspension, wide tyres and a rear spoiler, put the GTO back on the top spot.

cars.name: Porsche 356 A/1500 GS Carrera '56
description: Introduced in 1949, the 356 A is an improved version of the 356, Porsche's first mass produced model. Two versions were available, both featuring a detuned version of the engine from the 550 Spyder. The road model 1500 GS Carrera produced 98.6 BHP while the semi-racing 1500 GS GT produced 108.5 BHP. This car also marks the first appearance of Porsche's now iconic 'Carrera' sub-model name.

cars.name: Porsche 356 A/1500 GS GT Carrera Speedster '56
description: Porsche's first mass-production sports car, debuting in 1949. Models released from 1955 to 1959 were known as the 356 A. The engine is based on the unit from the 550 Spyder. The semi-racing car 1500 GS GT Carrera version produced 108.5 BHP and is the origin of the 'Carrera' badge.
cars.descriptionText: Porsche's first mass-production sports car, debuting in 1949. Models released from 1955 to 1959 were known as the 356 A. The engine is based on the unit from the 550 Spyder. cars.name: Porsche 911 Carrera RS (901) '73
description: The first model in the history of the Porsche 911 to bear the 'RS' badge was the 911 Carrera RS 2.7, released in 1973. RS stands for 'Rennsport' or literally 'racing sport' in English. This car was developed for homologation in the FIA's Group 4 category. It proved to be very popular, with its original planned run of 500 units selling out instantly. Porsche subsequently increased production numbers and in total 1,580 of these cars were produced.

cars.name: Porsche 911 Carrera RS (964) '92
description: In 1989, Porsche unveiled the 3rd generation 911, known as the type 964. Though styled almost identically to the previous 911, it was actually a major evolution with roughly 80% new parts. The four-wheel drive Carrera 4 was introduced first, with the rear-wheel drive Carrera 2 introduced in 1990. This Carrera RS is a performance tuned model based on the Carrera 2.

cars.name: Porsche 911 Carrera RS (993) '95
description: The Porsche 911 reached its 4th generation model in 1993 with the release of the type 993. Along with an update to the styling, the suspension was also improved for better handling. The most powerful grade was the Carrera RS, introduced in 1995, which had a more rigid yet lighter body. It also featured the final air-cooled engine in a 993, a 3.8L flat-6 unit producing 295.9 BHP. A circuit-oriented Carrera RS Club Sport model was also available.

cars.name: Porsche 911 Carrera RS CS (993) '95
description: The 4th gen type 993 Porsche 911 was introduced in a full model change in 1993. In 1995 came the Carrera RS with a more rigid yet lighter body and a 295.9 BHP 3.8L flat-6 engine. The lineup also featured the Carrera RS Club Sport. Set up for on-track usage, it included a large front spoiler and rear wing, as well as a welded roll cage.
cars.descriptionText: The 4th gen type 993 Porsche 911 was introduced in a full model change in 1993. Set up for on-track usage, it included a large front spoiler and rear wing, as well as a welded roll cage.

cars.name: Porsche 911 GT1 Strassenversion '97
description: The 911 GT1 Strassenversion is a road-legal version of the 911 GT1 race car which Porsche had developed for GT races between 1996 and 1998. The lights have been converted to the same configuration as the type 996, but the basic construction of the car is almost exactly the same as the racing version. In order to meet emissions requirements, the engine has been detuned to 536.5 BHP and yet the car is still capable of a 0-62.1 mph time of 3.7s and a top speed of 191.4 mph.

cars.name: Porsche 911 GT3 (996) '01
description: Originally introduced in 1997, the 996 model 911 was the first to receive a GT3 model. Using the highly rigid Carrera 4 body as a base, racing level upgrade parts have been employed in the suspension and brakes, while the engine uses a GT1 crank case fit for higher revolutions. 1889 units were produced in total.

cars.name: Porsche 911 GT3 (997) '09
description: A GT3 specification model introduced for the 997 model 911 in 2006. Using the Carrera 4 model as a base, the chassis and brakes have been upgraded in the same manner as the previous 996 model. The original 3.6L engine was enlarged to 3.8L in 2008 to produce 428 BHP. It also included electronically controlled PASM shocks as standard.

cars.name: Porsche 911 GT3 R (992) '22
description: The 911 GT3 R is a pure racing machine developed from the 992 model 911, the 8th generation of Porsche's everyday sports car. Announced in 2022, this machine is equipped with a naturally aspirated 4.2L flat-6 engine, producing a maximum 557.2 BHP. It also features lightweight carbon body panels and aramid fibre components, as well as the double wishbone/multilink suspension setup from the 911 RSR.

cars.name: Porsche 911 GT3 RS (991) '16
description: This high performance model is a further improved version of the 991 model Porsche 911 GT3. Starting with the wide body of the 911 Turbo, the front and rear track width has been increased, alongside major weigh reductions and aerodynamic improvements. Now enlarged to 4L, the engine produces 493.1 BHP and was able to set a lap time of 7m20s on the Nürburgring Nordschleife.

cars.name: Porsche 911 GT3 RS (992) '22
description: The Porsche 911 GT3 RS (992) is a high-performance street car that features aero parts from the 911 GT3 R race car. The car is equipped with a number of highly advanced aerodynamics systems, such as a large, swan-neck rear wing equipped with DRS (drag reduction system), and an adjustable active diffuser which acts as an air brake on hard braking.

cars.name: Porsche 911 RSR (991) '17
description: This race car carries on the spirit of the RSR. It was developed in a completely different process to the 911 road car. The 4L naturally aspirated engine is the first in 911 history to ever mounted midship and produces 502 BHP. At the 2017 Nürburgring 24 Hours, the car put on a magnificent performance sitting in the leading position for much of the race.

cars.name: Porsche 911 Turbo (930) '81
description: Introduced in 1975, this 911 Turbo was the first in Porsche production model history to feature the 'Turbo' badge. As this badge suggests, the 3L air-cooled flat-6 engine has been equipped with a KKK turbocharger, allowing it to produce 256.4 BHP. It also allowed the car to reach a cruising speed of 155.3 mph, an astonishing achievement for its time. From 1977, the engine displacement was enlarged to 3.3L and equipped with an air-to-air intercooler, allowing it to produce even more power.

cars.name: Porsche 911 Turbo S (992) '20
description: Having served as the icon of the Porsche brand since the 1960s, the 911 would reach its 8th generation in 2018 with the type 992 model. In April 2020, the Turbo S was added to the 992 family as the top performance model. The twin-turbo 3,745 cc flat-6 engine produces 641 BHP/81.6 kgfm and pushes this explosive power through all 4 wheels for a 0-62.1 mph time of 2.7s and a top speed of 205.1 mph.

cars.name: Porsche 917 LIVING LEGEND
description: The 917 achieved a number of glorious race results for Porsche, including winning 7 of 10 races at the 1970 World Sportscar Championship. The Porsche 917 LIVING LEGEND is a hypercar inspired by that 917. The classic façade of its design conceals a cutting-edge technology. Its high-level combination of top speed and downforce allow for rock-steady stability even at over 186.4 mph.

cars.name: Porsche 917K '70
description: The 917K is a prototype racing car designed by Porsche for use in sports car racing. While weighing just 800 kg, the 1970 917's engine was able to produce up to 591.7 BHP in its most powerful configuration. In 1970, its second year of competition, it was nearly unrivalled, winning 7 out of 10 rounds in the International Championship for Makes, and gave Porsche their long-awaited first victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

cars.name: Porsche 918 Spyder '13
description: The Porsche 918 Spyder is a super sports car released by Porsche in 2011. Succeeding the Carrera GT, it was sold in a limited run of 918 units as per its name. Its most notable feature is that it is a plug-in hybrid. The midship-mounted 599.6 BHP 4.6L V8 engine is assisted by 2 electric motors on the front axle, and one on the rear for a total system output of up to 873.8 BHP.

cars.name: Porsche 919 Hybrid '16
description: A prototype sports car developed to compete in the WEC and Le Mans. The 2L V4 turbo engine is part of a hybrid system with an energy recovery system that provides a total output of 887.6 BHP. From 2015 to 2017, it dominated the WEC winning both the constructors and drivers title each year.

cars.name: Porsche 959 '87
description: The Porsche 959 is a production version of the 'Gruppe B' prototype, itself developed by Porsche for competition in Group B, the top category of the WRC at the time. It features an advanced, electronically controlled four-wheel drive system that allows the driver to select the drivetrain mode to fit conditions, achieving not only excellent stability, but comfort as well. The disbanding of Group B meant it was never able to compete in the WRC, but it managed to achieve admirable results in other fields of racing.

cars.name: Porsche 962 C '88
description: The Porsche 962 C is a prototype race car that debuted in the World Endurance Championship (WEC) in 1985. Over its career, it would earn Porsche a number of race wins and championship titles. In its debut year at the WEC, it won 7 of 10 races, then in 1986, it won 4 out of 9 rounds at the renamed World Sports Prototype Championship (WSPC). In the 1987 WSPC it would take victory at Le Mans, and 2nd place the next year.

cars.name: Porsche Carrera GT '04
description: The Porsche Carrera GT is a mid-ship super sports car that was produced between 2003 and 2006, totalling 1270 units. The chassis is based around a lightweight yet rigid carbon fibre monocoque, with carbon fibre subframes to mount the engine and rear suspension. The engine is a 5.7L naturally aspirated V10 unit based on a racing engine and produced 603.5 BHP. This is linked to a 6-speed manual transmission.

cars.name: Porsche Carrera GTS (904) '64
description: In 1963, Porsche developed Carrera GTS in accordance with the World Sportscar Championship regulations of the time. In order to clear the 100-production-unit homologation requirement, the car used a ladder-frame chassis with a lightweight fibreglass body. It had excellent performance and won many of the major races, starting with the Targa Florio, and became the backbone of Porsche's GT racing efforts of the 1960s.

cars.name: Porsche Cayman GT4 '16
description: The Cayman GT4 is a motorsports oriented model that was added to the Porsche Cayman lineup in 2015. The engine is based on the 3.8L flat-6 from the 911 Carrera S, attached to a 6-speed manual transmission. Producing 379.7 BHP, it is more powerful than the base 911 Carrera and also features brake and suspension parts from the 991 model 911 GT3. A roll cage and 6-point seatbelts were also available as options.

cars.name: Porsche Cayman GT4 Clubsport '16
description: A pure racing car introduced for the Cayman's motorsports oriented GT4 grade. It uses the same 379.7 BHP producing 3.8L flat-6 engine as the GT4 model, but otherwise it has been perfectly modified for racing victory, removing all comfort items and employing parts from the 911 GT3 Cup car.

cars.name: Porsche Mission X '23
description: This all-electric hypercar was unveiled on 8 June 2023, exactly 75 years after the approval of the Porsche's first car, the 356 'No.1' Roadster. The exterior features motifs from the company's long history of race cars, and a highly sports driving focused cockpit. The car achieves a power-to-weight ratio of 1 horsepower per 1 kg and produces significantly more downforce than the 992 model 911 GT3 RS.

cars.name: Porsche Porsche VGT
description: This lightweight hyper performance machine carries on the traditions of Porsche while providing a message to the future of sports cars. The exterior and interior seamlessly blend together to create the most immersive driving experience possible. The power unit uses dual electric motors, while the novel active aero system adapts to provide the optimum aerodynamics for the conditions at hand.

cars.name: Porsche Porsche VGT Spyder
description: A Spyder version of the Porsche Vision Gran Turismo, itself unveiled in 2021. The exterior and interior seamlessly blend together to create the most immersive driving experience possible. The power unit uses dual electric motors, while the novel active aero system adapts to provide the optimum aerodynamics for the conditions at hand.

cars.name: Porsche Spyder type 550/1500RS '55
description: Sold from 1954, the 550/1500RS is a racing sports car featuring a steel tube frame with an aluminium body and a 4-cam flat-4 engine producing 133.1 BHP. It would achieve excellent results on the circuit, claiming class victory in both the 1954 and 1955 24 Hours of Le Mans. This 1500RS a particularly valuable example, featuring the same original paint that it wore at the 1956 24 Hours of Le Mans.

cars.name: Porsche Taycan Turbo S '19
description: The Taycan is Porsche's first full electric sports saloon. The four-wheel drive system features electric motors on each of the front and rear axles, and has been combined with a 2-speed transmission to achieve both incredible acceleration and top speeds. The overboost equipped Turbo S model produces 560 kW (750.5 BHP). It uses the first 800V electrical system in a mass production vehicle which offers benefits for both power unit efficiency and charging times.

cars.name: Radical SR3 SL '13
description: The Radical SR3 SL is a road-going race car that resembles a small Le Mans Prototype car. It is available with a Ford EcoBoost 295.9 BHP 2L inline-4 direct injection turbo as an option, connected to a 6-speed sequential paddle shift transmission. Weighing just 775 kg, the car is capable of stunning statistics, able to reach 59.7 mph in just 3.4s from a standing start and a top speed of 159.7 mph.

cars.name: RE Amemiya RE Amemiya FD3S RX-7
description: The Amemiya µ Boost up 7 is a street machine created by the RE Amemiya corporation, a legendary tuner of rotary engines renowned for their activities in the Super GT and D1GP. This car is known for maximizing the potential of the FD3S as a cornering machine. Among its accolades as a winding road specialist, it was featured in the Japanese DVD magazine 'Hot Version' where it was dubbed the 'demon-lord of mountain paths' due to its unbeatable speed.

cars.name: Renault Avantime 3.0 V6 24V '02
description: The Avantime is a speciality car designed by Patrick le Quément of Renault Design. The novel body design combines the underpinnings of the 3rd gen Espace, which had proved popular in Europe, with a fibreglass 3-door body. While coupé-like, what makes this car truly unique is the B-pillarless side windows and large sunroof which can all be opened. An embodiment of the character of Renault, this car proved that monoform design wasn't just for minivans.

cars.name: Renault Clio R.S. 220 Trophy '15
description: The Clio R.S. 220 EDC Trophy is a sports version of the 4th generation Clio developed by Renault Sport. This version is known as the R.S. Vision and features a novel new bumper designed to evoke the image of a chequered flag. It also features new LED front and tail lights, and other new design innovations throughout.

cars.name: Renault Clio V6 24V '00
description: Originally developed for motorsports, the Renault Clio R.S. V6 features the 3L V6 engine from the luxury Laguna model, producing a maximum 229.8 BHP. In 2002, the 'Phase 2' facelift model increased the output to 251.5 BHP along with other updates to the exterior, interior, and tyre size.

cars.name: Renault Espace F1 '95
description: 10 years after the debut of Europe's first minivan came the Renault Espace F1, an unprecedented monster machine. The 'RS4' 3.5L V10 engine from the 1992 F1 championship winning FW14B is mounted in the centre of the body, which is now made of aluminium and carbon fibre. Producing 788 BHP, the car is able to accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in 2.8s, reaching a top speed of 196.4 mph. This car was also driven on an actual circuit by F1 driver Alain Prost among others.

cars.name: Renault Kangoo 1.4 '01
description: In French, small vans are known as 'fourgonette'. The Kangoo gained mass support thanks to its sliding passenger doors and split back seats, which made it perfect for not just commercial, but personal leisure use as well. It would become the forerunner of 'ludospace'—leisure activity vehicles. Though the engine offers the bare minimum in power, the soft suspension makes for a lively driving experience.

cars.name: Renault Mégane Gr.4
description: This Gran Turismo Original is a version of the Renault's fastest hatchback, the Mégane, modified for Gr.4 rules. The Mégane has already set an incredible time on the Nürburgring so it's only natural it has great potential as a race car. The superb traction and cornering ability will make you forget this is a front-wheel drive car.

cars.name: Renault Mégane R.S. Trophy '11
description: Based on the 3rd generation Mégane 3-door coupé, the Mégane R.S. is factory tuned by Renault Sport. Featuring unique ground effects and a newly developed chassis, the car is able to take corners at speeds that easily crown it as the fastest front-wheel drive. In 2011, the Mégane R.S. Trophy was released. Limited to 500 cars worldwide, it would set a new record for mass-produced front-wheel drive cars at the Nürburgring with a lap time of 8 minutes, 7.97 seconds.

cars.name: Renault Mégane R.S. Trophy Safety Car
description: This fictional safety car is based on the Mégane R.S. Trophy, which was released in a limited run of 500 cars in 2011. The 'R.S.' is a high performance version of the Mégane created by Renault Sport, but the Trophy version modifies this even further with an increased engine output and extensive suspension tuning in a bid to create the world's fasted front-wheel drive production car.

cars.name: Renault Mégane Trophy '11
description: The Renault Sport Mégane Trophy was developed for use in Mégane Trophy race which started in 2005. While keeping the general image of the Mégane intact, the Trophy features more aggressive styling with a 3.5L V6 tuned to 355 BHP mounted in the 995 kg body. The transmission is a 6-speed 2-pedal manual transmission with paddle shifters. The suspension and brakes are full racing spec.

cars.name: Renault R.S.01 '16
description: In summer 2014, Renault Sport released the R.S.01 as the new machine for one-make racing, taking the place of the Mégane Trophy. Though 4,170 mm long and 2,000 mm wide, the body weighs just 1,100 kg. This light frame is powered by a V6 twin-turbo engine producing 542.4 BHP. The car offers all anyone could ask for in a race car, with all of Renault Sport's extensive know-how present in the aerodynamics and cooling parts.

cars.name: Renault R.S.01 GT3 '16
description: Based on Renault Sport's one-make race machine, the R.S.01, the Renault Sport R.S.01 GT3 was developed for use in FIA-GT championships. This model features numerous changes to conform with FIA (Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile) GT3 regulations. The power output has been limited and brake materials have been changed, in addition to 50 kg of ballast and completely revised ground effects.

cars.name: Renault R4 GTL '85
description: The Renault 4 ('Quatre') was introduced in 1961 to replace Renault's bestselling 4CV. This grandfather of the modern hatchback reached its full potential in 1978 with the GTL. This model added a plastic front grille and a powerful 1.1L engine, along with a modern instrument panel. The Renault 4 would gain an enormous following, and roughly 8,135,000 units were produced up until 1992. A car for the people, this is one of the greats of French automotive design.

cars.name: Renault R5 Turbo '80
description: The Renault R5 ('Cinq') Turbo received much attention on its unveiling at the 1978 Paris Motor Show. Originally a prototype for competition in the World Rally Championship (WRC), a production model was introduced in 1980. The car was drastically modified, switching from a front-engine front-wheel drive layout to a mid-engine rear-wheel drive layout. Compared to the basic 5, the new engine produced 1.5 times as much power and 3.3 times as much torque. Debuting at the WRC Tour de Corse in 1980, it swept the field across a number of events, leaving Renault's mark on WRC history.

cars.name: Renault R8 Gordini '66
description: This high-performance model of the Renault 8 was tuned by Amédée Gordini, nicknamed 'The Sorcerer' for his work on engines. This car masterfully utilises the merits of the base 8's design, transforming the unassuming 1,108 cc compact saloon into a hard-boiled touring car. In 1966, the engine was enlarged to 1,300 cc and the transmission changed to a 5-speed unit, further increasing its potential. Thanks to its unique design, this automotive masterpiece has a special place in the hearts of fans even now.

cars.name: Roadster Shop Roadster Shop Rampage
description: Winner of the 2014 Gran Turismo Award. This 1970 Chevrolet Camaro SS has been customised by Roadster Shop in Illinois, United States. The basic construction has been recreated from scratch using carbon fibre and aluminium parts, and equipped with a 7L LS7 engine offset to the rear and tuned to 739.6 BHP. This power is matched by the stunning looks provided by its large overfenders, front spoiler and rear wing.

cars.name: RUF CTR3 '07
description: Released in 2007, the RUF CTR3 is the successor to the CTR and CTR2. While previous models were based on the Porsche 930 and 993 Turbo, the CTR3 was designed and developed from scratch by RUF. It uses a midship layout with a 3.8L flat-6 intercooled twin turbo engine. It has a top speed of 236.1 mph and a 0-62.1 mph acceleration time of 3.2s.

cars.name: RUF RGT 4.2 '16
description: This RUF original is based on the 991 model Porsche 911 GT3. Built around the theme of combining GT3 performance with road car comfort, this car features a naturally aspirated Mezger engine, assembled with the legendary GT1 crank, and enlarged from 3.8L to 4.2L. The exterior is accented by rivetted overfenders which serve to clearly state the car's ferocity. An excellent choice for a gentleman driver.

cars.name: Shelby Cobra 427 '66
description: Shelby developed the Cobra 427 to win the FIA Speed World Challenge in which they were competing at the time. The car was equipped with a 7L 427 'Side Oiler', a pure racing engine for stock cars. To keep up with its impressive 493.1 BHP the car dropped its characteristic side-mounted leaf suspension for a new double wishbone layout.

cars.name: Shelby Cobra Daytona Coupe '64
description: The AC Cobra had dominated the racing scene of the 1960s, and its coupé version was the Shelby Cobra Coupé. The AC Cobra performed well in races thanks to its excellent acceleration and handling, but fell behind its rivals due to the aerodynamic inefficiency of its open body. Thanks to the coupé body designed by Pete Brock though, aerodynamics were significantly improved, adding over 18.6 mph to the top speed. With its true potential realised, the car would go on to win a number of races over the next 2 years.

cars.name: Shelby G.T.350 '65
description: This high performance Mustang was created by Ford and Carroll Shelby in a bid for victory in the SCCA, an American sports car racing series. The lightened body has been fitted with racing suspension and an LSD, while at the heart lies the 289 engine producing 301.8 BHP. It would dominate the series for 3 years running starting in 1965.

cars.name: Škoda Škoda VGT
description: A Czech manufacturer with 130 years of history behind it, Škoda's Gran Turismo debut model is an 800kW (1,071 BHP) single seater EV. The exterior features motifs from its forebearer classics alongside a wealth of cutting edge technologies such as the left-right independent active rear wings that adapt to driving conditions, and onboard distance sensors that judge the position of other cars.

cars.name: Subaru BRZ Drift Car '17
description: The 2017 'Falken Tire / Turn 14 Distribution BRZ' was driven by Formula Drift champion Daijiro 'Daichan' Yoshihara. It is based on the Rocket Bunny V3 aero kit and is equipped with a 7L turbocharged V8 engine producing roughly 986.2 BHP. Fitted with a 4-speed transmission and upgraded drivetrain parts, it would finish 6th in the 2017 season but left a strong impression.

cars.name: Subaru BRZ GT300 '21
description: From 2012, Subaru began competing with the BRZ in Japan's domestic 'Super GT' racing series GT300 class. Following the introduction of the base model's 2nd generation in 2021, Subaru switched over to a new GT machine based on 2nd gen BRZ. It carried over the strengths of the old model like the EJ20 engine, while implementing improvements to weight distribution and aerodynamics. In 2021, the BRZ was crowned the GT300 class series champion in a historic first for Subaru.

cars.name: Subaru BRZ S '15
description: The Toyota 86 and Subaru BRZ sports cars were developed in a tag-team effort between Toyota and Subaru. 'BRZ' stands for 'Boxer engine', 'Rear-wheel drive' and 'Zenith.' The engine combines the classic Subaru 2L boxer unit with Toyota's 'D-4S' direct injection technology. The car would receive almost yearly updates after its release in 2012. The 2015 model greatly improved the handling and ride feel.

cars.name: Subaru BRZ S '21
description: The Toyota 86 and Subaru BRZ boxer engine, rear-wheel drive sports cars were developed in a tag-team effort between Toyota and Subaru. The series would evolve to the 2nd generation ZD8 model in 2020. The new body was lighter yet more rigid, while the engine was a newly developed boxer unit with a larger displacement at 2.4L. Its maximum output is 231.8 BHP. The Subaru BRZ 'S' grade featured here is a high-end model with upgraded interior and exterior fittings.

cars.name: Subaru BRZ STI Sport '18
description: The BRZ STI Sport was introduced in 2017 as the top grade model of the BRZ lineup. It was developed in a joint effort between Subaru and their motorsports division, STI (Subaru Tecnica International). The most notable change is the body setup. Handling response and stability have been improved through the use of STI's proprietary Flexible V-Bar and Flexible Draw Stiffener parts, while specially developed suspension parts have increased agility.

cars.name: Subaru Impreza 22B-STi '98
description: A limited edition model based on the Impreza WRX STi Version IV. The body features blister fenders identical to the World Rally car, and a 2.2L boxer engine producing 276.1 BHP/37.0 kgfm. Though priced at 5M yen, all 400 sold out within days, making this one of the most sought after models among fans.

cars.model: Impreza Coupe WRX Type R STi Ver.VI '99
cars.name: Subaru Impreza Coupe WRX Type R STi Ver.VI '99
description: This is a coupé model of the Impreza Version VI, released in September 1999. Along with rally car stylings, it also features the Driver's Control Centre Differential (DCCD), an intercooler water sprayer, specially tuned hard suspension, and an upgraded rear axle as standard. The classic EJ20 engine has been tuned to produce 276.1 BHP, making this the comprehensive GC8.
cars.descriptionText: This is a coupé model of the Impreza Version VI, released in September 1999. Along with rally car stylings, it also features the Driver's Control Centre Differential (DCCD), an intercooler water sprayer, specially tuned hard suspension, and an upgraded rear axle as standard. The classic EJ20 engine has been tuned to produce 276.1 BHP, making this the comprehensive GC8.

cars.name: Subaru Impreza Rally Car '98
description: This WRC machine is based on the 2-door Impreza. Starting from the 1997 model, this evolution adds computer controlled active differentials in the front, rear and centre. While it was unable to secure Subaru a 4th consecutive constructors title, driver Colin McRae claimed victory in the Portugal, Tour de Corse and Acropolis rallies, proving that it had the potential.

cars.name: Subaru Impreza Sedan WRX STi '04
description: The first facelift of the GD Impreza is recognizable by its teardrop shaped 'blob eye' headlights. Engine efficiency has been increased through equal length matched exhaust headers. Some manual models also featured a Driver's Control Center Differential with auto mode. A further minor change in 2004 increased the tyre size and increased the torque output to 42.0 kgfm.

A further minor change in 2004 increased the tyre size and increased the torque output to 42.0 kgfm.

cars.name: Subaru VIZIV GT VGT
description: The 'SUBARU VIZIV GT Vision Gran Turismo' is Subaru's ultimate sports car, continuing with their concept of 'VIZIV', Vision for Innovation. The car uses carbon materials throughout the body and weighs 1,380 kg. With a special 2L horizontally-opposed engine and high powered electric motors, the combined drive system produces a maximum 591.7 BHP with a maximum torque of 800Nm (82 kgfm).

cars.name: Subaru WRX Gr.3
description: A Gran Turismo Original, Subaru's high performance WRX sedan has been modified to meet Gr.3 regulations. In order to reduce size of the front cross-sectional area, the lower chassis has been cut down and car height lowered as far as possible. Thanks to its diffuser style front splitter and 2-level rear wing, this 4-door sedan produces more downforce than a coupé.
cars.descriptionText: A Gran Turismo Original, Subaru's high performance WRX sedan has been modified to meet Gr.3 regulations. In order to reduce size of the front cross-sectional area, the lower chassis has been cut down and car height lowered as far as possible. Thanks to its diffuser style front splitter and 2-level rear wing, this 4-door sedan produces more downforce than a coupé.

cars.name: Subaru WRX Gr.4
description: A Gran Turismo Original, Subaru's high performance WRX sedan has been modified to meet Gr.4 regulations. A front splitter and rear wing have been added to increase downforce and improve cornering. The four-wheel drive system of the base car has been carried over giving it the best traction out of all the Gr.4 cars.
cars.descriptionText: A Gran Turismo Original, Subaru's high performance WRX sedan has been modified to meet Gr.4 regulations. A front splitter and rear wing have been added to increase downforce and improve cornering. cars.name: Subaru WRX Gr.B Rally Car
description: A Gran Turismo Original, Subaru's high performance WRX sedan has been modified to meet Gr.B regulations. To increase downforce and manoeuvrability, the track width has been greatly increased and long stroke suspension has been installed for better off-road performance, which all results in a cutting edge rally machine.
cars.descriptionText: A Gran Turismo Original, Subaru's high performance WRX sedan has been modified to meet Gr.B regulations. To increase downforce and manoeuvrability, the track width has been greatly increased and long stroke suspension has been installed for better off-road performance, which all results in a cutting edge rally machine.

cars.name: Subaru WRX Gr.B Road Car
description: A homologation model of the WRX Gr.B, a version of Subaru's high performance WRX sedan modified to meet Gr.B regulations. Though based on a rally car, more attention has been paid to on-road performance, adding a race car style front splitter, side skirt winglets and a rear diffuser.
cars.descriptionText: A homologation model of the WRX Gr.B, a version of Subaru's high performance WRX sedan modified to meet Gr.B regulations. Though based on a rally car, more attention has been paid to on-road performance, adding a race car style front splitter, side skirt winglets and a rear diffuser.

cars.name: Subaru WRX STI Isle of Man '16
description: In June 2016, a Subaru WRX STI set a new record for 4-wheeled cars in a time attack at the Isle of Man Tourist Trophy race. The WRX STI had been competing in this event since 2011, but the 2016 machine was constructed by Prodrive of Britain, who had won numerous World Rally Championship titles. As a result, they were able to shave the record down by almost 2 minutes to 17:35.139, achieving an average speed of 128.6 mph.

The WRX STI had been competing in this event since 2011, but the 2016 machine was constructed by Prodrive of Britain, who had won numerous World Rally Championship titles. As a result, they were able to shave the record down by almost 2 minutes to 17:35.139, achieving an average speed of 128.6 mph.

cars.name: Subaru WRX STI Type S '14
description: Announced in autumn 2013, the Subaru WRX is a mid-class saloon, now independent from the Impreza line. Using almost the same platform as the Levorg, the WRX has been significantly reinforced. The high powered STI edition features even better performance, with newly developed suspension and a refined version of the EJ20, now producing 303.7 BHP/43 kgfm.

cars.name: Super Formula SF19 Super Formula / Honda '19
description: The Japanese Super Formula series switched over to the Dallara SF19 in 2019. It uses a halo system that meets F1 safety standards, and aerodynamic improvements over the previous SF14 model makes overtaking easier. The engine is a 2L inline-4 direct injection turbo with 2 versions independently developed by Toyota and Honda. There is a very fierce development competition within the strict regulations.

It uses a halo system that meets F1 safety standards, and aerodynamic improvements over the previous SF14 model makes overtaking easier. The engine is a 2L inline-4 direct injection turbo with 2 versions independently developed by Toyota and Honda. There is a very fierce development competition within the strict regulations.

cars.name: Super Formula SF23 Super Formula / Honda '23
description: The Dallara SF23 Super Formula debuted in the spring of 2023 as the new car for the Super Formula series. As per the 'SUPER FORMULA NEXT50' project goal of making motorsports sustainable, the car uses bio-composite materials and CO2 emissions have been greatly reduced. Engines are supplied by Toyota and Honda.
